rComments: Take the course with another prof if possible. His criteria are very vague and he sets unclear expectations for assignments. Might be helpful to go over the page limit because he expects a lot more detail than he mentions in the rubric.

In one class I took, I followed his word counts and got a C+ (he said I wasn't specific enough - I would have been if I had more space to work with!). My classmates quadrupled the word count and got As. In another course, he kept docking marks for going over the page limit!! I guess just be as concise as you can. He likes clear, simple writing.

This is an intro level course I had with the prof. The course outline is detailed and organized, but not that is not the case for everything else. There is a major disconnect between each assessment and what is expected, so beware of that.

Prof does not set expectations for assignments. Unclear until after the fact. Even then, some of the feedback is more of his personal approach to writing rather than being open to other ways. Often seems confused by his own course outline and course set-up, which makes him very disorganized. Nice, but all over the place.

Reis gives TINY word count goals and then penalizes for 'not being specific enough' or whatever. Ignore page limits. Quadruple it if you must. Use examples. Be careful with citations and expand/explain everything in detail. He's esoteric but knowledgeable. His feedback is pretty useful, but tough.

Professor Reis is very likeable and is is obvious that he is passionate about teaching and that he cares about his students. However, he can come off as too relaxed and unorganized. I feel like I did not really learn much from his course. If you're someone who needs structure and valuable feedback than I wouldn't take any courses from this prof.
A nice person but far from a fair evaluator. Avoid his courses at all cost.
